titleStmt.title: William Warriner to Thomas E. BRamlette
CWG5112

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: State of Kentucky Russell County SS

William Warriner States that he was indicted by the Grand Jury of Russell County and at the April Term of the Russell Circuit Court 1864 he was fined by said court the sum of $20 for keeping a tippling house at the Russell Springs in said County. He states that he had been keeping a tavern at said Springs under a license granted by the County Court which had expired and he was told by the United States assessor that he must take out a licence to keep a tavern which he done. under which license he continued to sell ardent spiritis and keep tavern under the impression that it was all sufficient and that their was no necessity for any other license under the State laws. States that he is a law abiding citizen & does not violate any of the laws willingly. He therefore respectfully askess the govenor of Kentucky to remit said fine so far as the Commonwealth is concerned and as in duty bound &c
Sworn to and subscribed by William Warriner before me an Examiner for Russell County this 18th day of June 1864
We the undersigned resident of Russell County join with the petitioner above for the remission of the fine as stated in the above petition

Achilles Nelson
S P.. Collins
George Bryan
W M Green

Russell Cir Ct
vs
W Warriner
Tipling
$20
